newsitem.title: FRANCE: New French minister pledges judicial independence.
newsitem.headline: New French minister pledges judicial independence.

text.p: France's new Socialist Justice Minister Elisabeth Guigou said on Thursday her top priority would be to restore confidence in the justice system and ensure its independence.
"It is indispensable to restore confidence," she said at a ceremony marking the transfer of power to the new government.

Guigou was a surprise choice for the justice portfolio as little in her background appeared to prepare her for the delicate task of fulfilling a Socialist campaign pledge to make the judiciary independent of political authorities.
Outgoing minister Jacques Toubon used the handover ceremony to take a swipe at the incoming government, saying it would have a hard time equalling his achievements.
"In terms of image, you will have no problem succeeding me and even surpassing me. This will not be so easy in terms of achievement," Toubon said.

Toubon, who lost his seat in last Sunday's parliamentary election, was accused by the media and by Socialists of derailing sleaze investigations targeting individuals and parties from the former centre-right majority.

In one highly publicised incident, his ministry chartered a helicopter last year to try to track down a state prosecutor trekking in Nepal in an unsuccessful attempt to head off an inquiry into Gaullist Paris mayor Jean Tiberi.

Judges unions welcomed Guigou's remarks. "The Socialist Party has made some precise commitments. We will now try to hold them to their word," said Jean-Pierre Boucher of the Syndicat de la Magistrature union.
Several major investigations involving the former centre-right majority have already been launched since Sunday's election.
In one case, a Paris judge placed three centrist former ministers under investigation in an investigation into alleged illegal funding of the Democratic Force party.
In a second case, a prosecutor opened an inquiry into suspected graft over public works contracts by the Paris regional council, led by an ally of conservative President Jacques Chirac.
